context: John drives for 3 hours at a speed of 60 mph and then turns around because he realizes he forgot something very important at home.  He tries to get home in 4 hours but spends the first 2 hours in standstill traffic.  He spends the next half-hour driving at a speed of 30mph, before being able to drive the remaining time of the 4 hours going at 80 mph.
main-q: How far is he from home at the end of those 4 hours?
qa-pairs: How far was John from home when he turned around?
When he turned around he was 3*60=<<3*60=180>>180 miles from home.
How many hours did John drive in the first four hours?
He was only able to drive 4-2=<<4-2=2>>2 hours in the first four hours.
How far does John drive in half an hour?
In half an hour he goes 30*.5=<<30*.5=15>>15 miles.
How many hours does John drive in the second four hours?
He then drives another 2-.5=<<2-.5=1.5>>1.5 hours.
How far does John drive in the second four hours?
In that time he goes 80*1.5=<<80*1.5=120>>120 miles.
How far did John drive in the second four hours?
How far is John from home at the end of those 4 hours?
So he is 180-135=<<180-135=45>>45 miles away from home.

context: Dana can run at a rate of speed four times faster than she can walk, but she can skip at a rate of speed that is half as fast as she can run.
main-q: If she can skip at 3 miles per hour, how many miles can she travel in six hours if she spends one-third of the time running and two-thirds of the time walking?
qa-pairs: How fast can Dana run?
If Dana can skip at half the speed she can run, then she can run at 3*2=<<3*2=6>>6 miles per hour.
How fast can Dana walk?
And since she can run at a speed that is 4 times faster than she can walk, this means she can walk at 6/4=1.5 miles per hour.
How many hours does Dana walk?
If two-thirds of the time is spent walking, then she walks for 6*(2/3)=<<6*(2/3)=4>>4 hours.
How many hours does Dana run?
If one-third of the time is spent running, then she runs for 6-4=<<6-4=2>>2 hours.
How many miles does Dana run?
Thus, she runs for 2 hours at 6 miles per hour, or 2*6=<<2*6=12>>12 miles.
How many miles does Dana walk?
She walks for 4 hours at 1.5 miles per hour, or 4*1.5=<<4*1.5=6>>6 miles.
How many miles does Dana travel?
Thus, altogether, she travels 12+6=<<12+6=18>>18 miles.

context: Artie has a flower stand at the Farmers Market. He sells three kinds of flowers: marigolds, petunias and begonias. He usually sells marigolds for $2.74 per pot, petunias for $1.87 per pot and begonias for $2.12 per pot. Artie has no change today, so he has decided to round all his prices to the nearest dollar.
main-q: If Artie sells 12 pots of marigolds, 9 pots of petunias and 17 pots of begonias, how much will he make?
qa-pairs: How much will Artie sell his marigolds for?
Artie will round his marigolds up from $2.74 to $3, since the number following the 2 is 5 or higher.
How much will Artie sell his petunias for?
Artie will round his petunias up from $1.87 to $2, since the number following the 1 is 5 or higher.
How much will Artie sell his begonias for?
Artie will round his begonias down from $2.12 to $2, since the number following the 2 is less than 5.
How much will Artie sell his marigolds for?
Artie sells 12 marigolds x $3 = $<<12*3=36>>36.
How much will Artie sell his petunias for?
Artie sells 9 petunias x $2 = $<<9*2=18>>18.
How much will Artie sell his begonias for?
Artie sells 17 begonias x $2 = $<<17*2=34>>34.
How much will Artie make?
Altogether, Artie will make $36 + $18 + $34 = $<<36+18+34=88>>88.

context: Frankie watches TV after he finishes his homework every night. On Monday and Tuesday, he watched a 1-hour episode of his favorite show each night. On Wednesday, he watched a few episodes of a 30-minute show. On Thursday, he finished homework early and watched a 1-hour episode and a 30-minute show. On Friday, he got to stay up late for the weekend, so he watched two 1-hour episodes.
main-q: If he watched 7 hours of TV in all, how many 30-minute episodes did he watch on Wednesday?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let W be the number of episodes he watched on Wednesday.
How many hours of TV did Frankie have left after Monday?
After Monday, he had 7 - 1 = <<7-1=6>>6 hours of TV left.
How many hours of TV did Frankie have left after Tuesday?
After Tuesday, he had 6 - 1 = <<6-1=5>>5 hours of TV left.
How many hours of TV did Frankie have left after Thursday?
After Thursday, he had 5 - 1 - 1/2 = 3 1/2 hours of TV left.
How many hours of TV did Frankie have left after Friday?
After Friday, he had 3 1/2 - 2 = 1 1/2 hours of TV left.
How many minutes are in each 30-minute episode?
Each 30-minute episode is 1/2 hour.
How many 30-minute episodes did Frankie watch on Wednesday?
Thus, W = 1 1/2 / 1/2 = 3 episodes.

context: Adrien's total salary was 30 percent higher than Lylah's. Four years later, his salary had increased, and he was earning 40% more than what he was making four years ago.
main-q: If Adrien's and Lylah's salary increased simultaneously, and Adrien earned $40000 four years ago, calculate the total salary the two were receiving four years later?
qa-pairs: How much did Adrien's raise amount to?
Since Adrien was earning $40000 four years ago and received a raise that makes him earn 40% more, he received a 40/100*$40000 = $<<40/100*40000=16000>>16000 raise.
How much did Adrien's salary increase?
In total, four years later, Adrien's salary is $40000+$16000 = $56000.
How much was Lylah's salary four years ago?
If four years ago Adrien was earning $40000, and Lylah's salary was 30% less, then Lylah's salary was 30/100*$40000= $12000 less than Adrien's salary four years ago.
How much was Lylah's salary four years ago?
Four years ago, Lylah was earning $40000-$12000 =$28000.
How much did Lylah's raise amount to?
How much does Lylah earn four years later?
In total, four years later, Lylah earns $28000+$11200= $<<28000+11200=39200>>39200.
How much do Adrien and Lylah earn four years later?
The total amount of salary the two earn four years later is $39200+$56000 = $<<39200+56000=95200>>95200.

context: There are 700 bees in a hive. There are twice as many worker bees as baby bees, and there are twice as many babies as queens.
main-q: How many worker bees are there?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x represent the number of queens.
How many baby bees are there?
Babies:2x.
How many worker bees are there?
Workers:2(2x)=4x.
Write an equation?
Total:x+2x+4x=700.
Combine like terms?
Divide by 7?
How many worker bees are there?
Workers:4(100)=400 worker bees.

context: Kim has started his own housekeeping business and is calculating how much profit he will make from his clients. He already has 3 clients, but is talking to another 5 potential clients and feels confident enough to include them in his calculations. Each client’s home will need 2 bottles of bleach and a pack of cloths to clean. Bottles of bleach will cost $2 each and packs of cloths will cost $5 each. These are his only expenses. He calculates that his total income each week will be $92.
main-q: Profit is the difference between total income and total expenses, so how much profit, in dollars, will Lucas make each week?
qa-pairs: How many clients does Lucas have?
Lucas counts a total of 3 confirmed clients + 5 potential clients = <<3+5=8>>8 clients.
How many bottles of bleach will Lucas need each week?
Each week, he will need a total of 8 clients * 2 bottles of bleach per client = <<8*2=16>>16 bottles of bleach.
How many packs of cloths will Lucas need each week?
Each week, he will also need a total of 8 clients * 1 pack of cloths per client = <<8*1=8>>8 packs of cloths.
How much will the bottles of bleach cost?
The bottles of bleach will cost him 16 bottles of bleach * $2 per bottle of bleach = $<<16*2=32>>32.
How much will the packs of cloths cost?
The packs of cloths will cost him 8 packs of cloths * $5 per pack of cloths = $<<8*5=40>>40.
How much will Lucas' total expenses be?
So each week, Lucas' total expenses will be $32 for bleach + $40 for packs of cloths = $<<32+40=72>>72.
How much will Lucas' profit be?
His profit will therefore be $92 total income - $72 total expenses = $<<92-72=20>>20.

context: On Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, college student Kimo has three 1-hour  classes each day.  On Tuesdays and Thursdays, he has two 2-hour classes each day.  In one semester, there are 16 weeks of school.
main-q: In one semester, how many hours does Kimo spend attending classes?
qa-pairs: How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays?
Kimo spends 3 x 1 = <<3*1=3>>3 hours in class on any given Monday, Wednesday or Friday.
How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Mondays, Wednesons and Fridays?
Each week, he spends 3 x 3 = <<3*3=9>>9 hours in class on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.
How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays?
In one semester, he spends 9 x 16 = <<9*16=144>>144 hours in class for Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.
How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Tuesdays and Thursdays?
He spends 2 x 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 hours in class on any given Tuesday or Thursday.
How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Tuesdays and Thursdays?
Each week, he spends 4 x 2 = <<4*2=8>>8 hours in class on Tuesday and Thursday.
How many hours does Kimo spend in class on Tuesdays and Thursdays?
In one semester, he spends 8 x 16 = <<8*16=128>>128 hours in class on Tuesday and Thursday.
How many hours does Kimo spend attending classes?
In total for one semester, Kimo spends 144 + 128 = <<144+128=272>>272 hours attending classes.

context: Anakin and Locsin went to the beach today. Anakin caught 10 starfish, 6 sea horses, and 3 clownfish. While Locsin caught 5 fewer starfish than Anakin, 3 fewer sea horses than Anakin, and 2 more clownfish than Anakin.
main-q: How many fish were they able to catch?
qa-pairs: How many starfish did Locsin catch?
Locsin caught 10 - 5 = <<10-5=5>>5 starfishes.
How many starfish did they catch?
They caught 10 + 5 = <<10+5=15>>15 starfishes.
How many seahorses did Locsin catch?
Locsin caught 6 - 3 = <<6-3=3>>3 seahorses.
How many seahorses did they catch?
They caught 6 + 3 = <<6+3=9>>9 seahorses.
How many clownfish did Locsin catch?
Locsin caught 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 clownfish.
How many clownfish did they catch?
So, they caught 3 + 5 = <<3+5=8>>8 clownfish.
How many fish were they ableus to catch?
Therefore, Anakin and Locsin were able to catch a total of 15 + 9 + 8 = <<15+9+8=32>>32 fish.

context: Zaid spends 1/4 of his salary on rent, 1/3 on car fuel and donates half of the remaining amount to his favorite charity. He gives his daughter 200$ to use for her weekly expenses and 700$ to his wife to budget for groceries and other household goods.
main-q: If Zaid earns 6000$ per month, how much money will he still have after all these expenses and donations?
qa-pairs: How much money does Zaid spend on rent?
When Zaid spend 1/4 of his salary on rent, he parts with 1/4*$6000 = $<<1/4*6000=1500>>1500.
How much money does Zaid spend on car fuel?
How much money does Zaid spend in total?
How much money does Zaid remain with?
The total amount of money he remains with is $6000-$3500 = $<<6000-3500=2500>>2500.
How much money does Zaid donate?
He donates half of the remaining amount, which is 1/2*$2500 = $<<1/2*2500=1250>>1250.
How much money does Zaid give to his wife and daughter?
The total amount of money given to his wife and daughter is $200+$700 = $<<200+700=900>>900.
How much money does Zaid still have after giving the wife and daughter?
After the amount that he gave the wife and daughter, the total amount remaining is $1250-$900 = $<<1250-900=350>>350.

context: Jerry has a flock of chickens. The red chickens produce 3 eggs a day, and the white chickens produce 5 eggs a day. Every day Jerry collects 42 eggs.
main-q: If he has two more white chickens than red chickens, how many red chickens does he have?
qa-pairs: How many eggs do the red and white chickens lay each day?
First, set up the equation for the number of eggs the chickens lay each day: 3r + 5w = 42, where r is the number of red chickens and w is the number of white chickens.
How many white chickens does Jerry have?
Then, express r in terms of w based on the information in the problem: w = r + <<+2=2>>2.
How many eggs do the red and white chickens lay each day?
Now substitute r + 2 for w in the equation for the number of eggs: 3r + 5(r + 2) = 42.
How many eggs do the red and white chickens lay each day?
Now multiply 5 through the parentheses: 3r + 5r + 10 = 42.
How many eggs do the red and white chickens lay each day?
Now add like terms to get 8r + 10 = 42.
How many eggs do the red and white chickens lay each day?
Now subtract 10 from both sides of the equation: 8r = 32.
How many red chickens does Jerry have?
Finally, divide both sides of the equation by 8 to get r = 4.

context: Jerry has two pools, both with leaks emptying them out at 4 gallons/minute. 4 minutes ago, the big pool had twice as much water as the small pool. Now the big pool has four times as much water as the small pool.
main-q: How much water does the small pool have now?
qa-pairs: How many gallons of water flow out of the pools in 4 minutes?
First find how many gallons of water flow out of the pools in 4 minutes: 4 gallons/minute * 4 minutes = <<4*4=16>>16 gallons.
How many gallons of water does the big pool have now?
Let b be the amount of water the big pool has now and s be the amount of water the small pool has. We know that b = 4s, and b + 16 = 2(s + 16).
How many gallons of water does the small pool have now?
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 4s + 16 = 2(s + 16).
How many gallons of water does the small pool have now?
Multiplying through the parentheses, we get 4s + 16 = 2s + 32.
How many gallons of water does the small pool have now?
Subtracting 2s from both sides, we get 2s + 16 = 32.
How many gallons of water does the small pool have now?
Subtracting 16 from both sides, we get 2s = 16.
How many gallons of water does the small pool have now?
Dividing both sides by 2, we get s = <<8=8>>8.

context: Adrian's age is three times the age of Harriet, and Harriet is half the age of Zack. Calculate the average age of the three in three years if Harriet is 21 years old now.
qa-pairs: How old will Harriet be in three years?
In three years, Harriet will be 21+3 = <<21+3=24>>24 years old.
How old is Adrian?
Since Adrian's age is three times that of Harriet, Adrian is 3*21 = <<3*21=63>>63 years old.
How old will Adrian be in three years?
In three years, he will be 63+3 =<<63+3=66>>66 years old.
How old is Zack?
If Harriet is half times the age of Zack, Zack is 21*2 = <<21*2=42>>42 years old.
How old will Zack be in three years?
In three years, he will be 42+3 = <<42+3=45>>45 years old.
How old will the three be in three years?
The combined age of the three in 3 years will be 45+66+24 = <<45+66+24=135>>135 years.
What is the average age of the three in three years?
The average age for the in three years will be 135/3 =<<135/3=45>>45 years.

context: Ruby is 6 times older than Sam. In 9 years, Ruby will be 3 times as old as Sam.
main-q: How old is Sam now?
qa-pairs: How old is Ruby now?
Let x be Sam's age and Y be Ruby's age. Ruby's age is currently 6 times Sam's age, so 6 * x = Y years.
How old will Ruby be in 9 years?
In 9 years Ruby's age will be 3 times Sam's age, so, 3 * (x + 9) = (Y + 9) years.
How old will Ruby be in 9 years?
To find out Sam's age, we substituted the first step in the second to get 3 * (x + 9) = (6 * x) + 9.
How old will Ruby be in 9 years?
We distribute on one side of the equation to get (3 * x) + 27 = (6 * x) + 9.
How old will Ruby be in 9 years?
We isolate Sam's age on one side of the equation to get 27 - 9 = (6 * x) - (3 * x).
How old will Ruby be in 9 years?
We simplify the equation to get 18 = 3 * x.
How old is Sam now?
Now we know that Sam's age is 18 / 3 = <<18/3=6>>6 years.

context: Nick is choosing between two jobs. Job A pays $15 an hour for 2000 hours a year, and is in a state with a 20% total tax rate. Job B pays $42,000 a year and is in a state that charges $6,000 in property tax and a 10% tax rate on net income after property tax.
main-q: How much more money will Nick make at the job with a higher net pay rate, compared to the other job?
qa-pairs: How much does Job A pay in total?
First calculate the gross annual salary for Job A: 2000 hours * $15/hour = $<<2000*15=30000>>30,000.
How much does Nick pay in total taxes at Job A?
Next, calculate the amount of taxes Nick pays at Job A by multiplying his net salary by the 20% tax rate: .2 * $30,000 = $<<30000*.2=6000>>6,000.
How much does Nick make at Job A?
Now subtract Nick's taxes from his net pay to find his gross pay at Job A: $30,000 - $6,000 = $<<30000-6000=24000>>24,000.
How much does Nick make at Job B?
Now subtract Nick's property taxes from his gross income at Job B: $42,000 - $6,000 = $<<42000-6000=36000>>36,000.
How much does Nick pay in income tax at Job B?
Now multiply Nick's income after property tax by 10% to find his income tax at Job B: $36,000 * 10% = $<<36000*10*.01=3600>>3,600.
How much does Nick make at Job B?
Now subtract the income tax amount from Nick's earnings after property tax to find his net income at Job B: $36,000 - $3,600 = $<<36000-3600=32400>>32,400.
How much more money will Nick make at the job with a higher net pay rate, compared to the other job?
Now subtract the net income from the lower-paying job (A) from the net income from the higher-paying job (B): $32,400 - $24,000 = $<<32400-24000=8400>>8,400.

context: Carolyn works for a delivery service company that hires on a contract basis. In May, they hired 40 employees, paying each employee $15 per hour for a 40-hour workweek. In June, 1/4 of the employees' contracts expired. Calculate the total amount of money the company paid to the employees in the two months.
qa-pairs: How much is each employee paid when hired?
When hired, each employee is paid $15*40 = $<<15*40=600>>600 per week.
How much is each employee paid in a month?
The total earnings of a contracted employee in a month are 4 weeks * $600 per week = $<<4*600=2400>>2400.
How much did the company pay to all of its contract employees in May?
Paying 40 employees, the company paid 40*$2400= $<<40*2400=96000>>96000 to all of its contract employees in May.
How many employees' contracts expired in June?
In June, 1/4 of the employees' contracts expired, that is 1/4*40 = <<1/4*40=10>>10 employees.
How many employees were still under contract in June?
The total number of employees whose contracts were valid in June was 40-10 = <<40-10=30>>30 employees.
How much did the company pay to the contracted employees in June?
The total amount of money paid to the contracted employees in June is 30*$2400 = $<<30*2400=72000>>72000.
How much did the company pay to the employees in the two months?
In the two months, the company paid a total of $72000+$96000 = $<<72000+96000=168000>>168000.

context: While Joanne is gathering apples from her family’s orchard, her sister comes outside to help her. Joanne gathers 30 apples from the tallest trees, half this amount from the shortest trees, and more apples from the average trees. Compared with Joanne, her sister gathers twice as many apples from the tallest trees and 3 times as many apples from the shortest trees. She doesn't take any from the average trees.
main-q: If the sisters have gathered a combined total of 500 apples, how many apples did Joanne gather from the average trees?
qa-pairs: How many apples did Joanna gather from the shortest trees?
Joanna gathered 30 apples / 2 = <<30/2=15>>15 apples from the shortest trees.
How many apples did her sister gather from the tallest trees?
Her sister gathered 30 apples * 2 = <<30*2=60>>60 apples from the tallest trees.
How many apples did her sister gather from the shortest trees?
Her sister also gathered 15 apples * 3 = <<15*3=45>>45 apples from the shortest trees.
How many apples did her sister gather?
In total, her sister gathered 60 + 45 = <<60+45=105>>105 apples.
How many apples did Joanna gather?
From the tallest and shortest trees, Joanna gathered 30 + 15 = <<30+15=45>>45 apples.
How many apples did the sisters have together?
So far, the sisters have a combined total of 105 + 45 = <<105+45=150>>150 apples.
How many apples did Joanna gather from the average trees?
Therefore, Joanna must have gathered 500 total apples – 150 apples so far = <<500-150=350>>350 apples from the average trees.

context: Jon runs a triathlon.  It takes him 40 minutes for the swim, an hour and 20 minutes for the bike ride and 50 minutes for the run.  Compared to Jon, James finishes the swim 10% faster but takes 5 minutes longer on the bike.
main-q: If Jon won by 10 minutes, how long did it take James to do the run?
qa-pairs: How long did Jon take to do the bike ride?
Jon did the bike ride in 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes.
How long did Jon take to do the triathlon?
So his total time was 40+80+50=<<40+80+50=170>>170 minutes.
How fast did James finish the swim?
James finished the swim 40*.1=<<40*.1=4>>4 minutes faster.
How long did James take to finish the swim?
So he finished the swim in 40-4=<<40-4=36>>36 minutes.
How long did James take to do the bike ride?
He finished the bike ride in 80+5=<<80+5=85>>85 minutes.
How long did James take to do the triathlon?
How long did James take to do the run?
So it took him 180-85-36=<<180-85-36=59>>59 minutes to do the run.

context: Elvis has a monthly saving target of $1125. In April, he wants to save twice as much daily in the second half as he saves in the first half in order to hit his target.
main-q: How much does he have to save for each day in the second half of the month?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let the amount he has to save for each day of the second half of April be y.
How much did he save in each day of the first half?
Since y is twice as much what he saved in each day of the first half, he saved y/2 in each day of the first half.
How much does he have to save for each day in the second half?
April has 30 days, 15 days in each half, so he is saving (15*(y/2)) in the 1st half, (15*y) in the 2nd half to give (15*(y/2))+(15*y)=$1125.
How much does he have to save for each day in the second half?
Solving the equation gives 15(3y/2) = $1125.
How much does he have to save for each day in the second half?
How much does he have to save for each day in the second half?
How much does he have to save for each day in the second half?

context: Tabitha agreed to pay John and Jill $10 an hour to help clean out her attic and basement.  Jill worked 2 hours on Saturday and 1 hour on Sunday.  John worked twice as long as Jill on Saturday and three times as long as Jill on Sunday.
main-q: How much more money did John earn compared to Jill?
qa-pairs: How many hours did Jill work?
Jill worked 2 hours + 1 hour for a total of 3 hours.
How much money did Jill make?
Jill worked 3 hours at $10/hour so she made 3*$10 = $<<3*10=30>>30.
How many hours did John work on Saturday?
John worked twice as long as Jill on Saturday so 2*2 = <<2*2=4>>4 hours.
How many hours did John work on Sunday?
John worked three times as long as Jill on Sunday so 3*1 = <<3*1=3>>3 hours.
How many hours did John work in total?
John worked 4 hours + 3 hours for 7 hours.
How much money did John make?
John worked 7 hours at $10/hour so he made 7*10 = $<<7*10=70>>70.
How much more money did John earn compared to Jill?
John made $70 while Jill made $30 so $70 - $30 = $<<70-30=40>>40 more dollars.

context: James hires a horse-drawn carriage from 5 PM to 9 PM.  He gets 1 hour free.  The first paid hour is $15 and each hour after that is twice the cost.
main-q: How much did he pay?
qa-pairs: How many hours did he get for free?
He got it for 9-5=<<9-5=4>>4 hours.
How many hours did he pay for?
He pays for 4-1=<<4-1=3>>3 hours.
How much did the first hour cost?
The first hour cost 1*15=$<<1*15=15>>15.
How much did the other hours cost?
The other 3-1=2 hours are more expensive.
How much did the other hours cost?
They cost 15*2=$<<15*2=30>>30 per hour.
How much did the other hours cost?
So those 2 hours cost 2*30=$<<2*30=60>>60.
How much did he pay?
So he pays 60+15=$<<60+15=75>>75 per hours.

context: Marcus ordered 5 croissants at $3.00 apiece, 4 cinnamon rolls at $2.50 each, 3 mini quiches for $4.00 apiece and 13 blueberry muffins that were $1.00 apiece.  At check out, Marcus shows his loyalty card that gives him 10% off of his purchase.
main-q: What is Marcus' total bill?
qa-pairs: How much do the croissants cost?
5 croissants cost $3.00 each so they cost 5*3 = $<<5*3=15.00>>15.00.
How much do the cinnamon rolls cost?
4 cinnamon rolls cost $2.50 each so they cost 4*2.5 =$<<4*2.5=10.00>>10.00.
How much do the mini quiches cost?
3 mini quiches cost $4.00 each so they cost 3*4 = $<<3*4=12.00>>12.00.
How much do the blueberry muffins cost?
13 blueberry muffins cost $1.00 each so the cost 13*1 = $<<13*1=13.00>>13.00.
How much do all the pastries cost?
How much does the coupon save him?
His has a 10% coupon for his $50.00 purchase so that saves him .10*50 = $<<10*.01*50=5.00>>5.00.
How much is his total bill?
His total bill is $50 minus his discount of $5.00 so 50-5 = $<<50-5=45.00>>45.00.

context: Bryce and four of his friends each ordered their own pizzas after football practice. Each pizza had 12 slices. Bryce and two friends ate 2/3 of their pizzas. The two remaining friends ate ¾ of their pizzas.
main-q: How many slices of pizza were left?
qa-pairs: How many slices of pizza were there?
Bryce and his 4 friends each ordered a pizza with 12 slices, so there were 5 pizzas x 12 slices per pizza = <<5*12=60>>60 slices of pizza.
How many slices of pizza did Bryce and his friends eat?
2/3 of a pizza with 12 slices would be the same as 8/12 because 2/3 x 4/4 = 8/12.
How many slices of pizza did Bryce and his friends eat?
Bryce and two of his friends each ate 2/3 or 8 slices of pizza, so 3 friends x 8 slices of pizza = 24 slices of pizza.
How many slices of pizza did Bryce and his friends eat?
¾ of a pizza with 12 slices would be the same as 9/12 because ¾ x 3/3 = 9/12.
How many slices of pizza did Bryce’s remaining friends eat?
Bryce’s two remaining friends each ate ¾ or 9 slices of pizza, so 2 friends x 9 slices = <<2*9=18>>18 slices of pizza.
How many slices of pizza did Bryce and his friends eat?
Together, Bryce and his friends ate 24 + 18 = <<24+18=42>>42 slices of pizza.
How many slices of pizza were left?
Of the 60 total slices of pizza, the friends ate 42, and 60 slices – 42 slices = <<60-42=18>>18 slices of pizza were left.

context: Jake's family wants to compare the cost of the two different amusement parks. The first amusement park has a $26 fee for each adult and a $12 fee for each child; while the second amusement park has a $14 fee for each adult and $10 for each child.
main-q: If there are 2 adults and 2 children in their family, how much will they be able to save if they choose the second amusement park over the first?
qa-pairs: How much do the two adults pay for the first amusement park?
The two adults pay $26 x 2 = $<<26*2=52>>52 for the first amusement park.
How much do the two children's tickets cost for the first amusement park?
While the two children's tickets cost $12 x 2 = $<<12*2=24>>24 for the first amusement park.
How much will they pay for the first amusement park?
So, they will pay a total of $52 + $24 = $<<52+24=76>>76 for the first amusement park.
How much do the two adults pay for the second amusement park?
The two adults pay $14 x 2 = $<<14*2=28>>28 for the second amusement park.
How much do the two children's tickets for the second amusement park cost?
While the two children's tickets for the second amusement park cost $10 x 2 = $<<10*2=20>>20.
How much will they pay for the second amusement park?
So, they will pay a total of $28 + $20 = $<<28+20=48>>48 for the second amusement park.
How much will they save if they choose the second amusement park over the first?
Thus, they will save $76 - $48 = $<<76-48=28>>28 if they choose the second amusement park over the first.

context: Rob, Royce, and Pedro are contractors getting ready to put a new roof on three homes. If the three homes will need 250 cases of shingles, with the first house needing 1/2 of the second, and the third needing double the first.
main-q: How many cases of shingles will the third house need?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x be the number of cases of shingles for the second house.
How many cases of shingles will the first house need?
The first house needs 1/2 x cases of shingles.
How many cases of shingles will the third house need?
The third house needs 2(1/2)x=x cases of shingles.
Set up an equation?
Combine like terms?
Multiply by (2/5)?
How many cases of shingles will the third house need?
The third house needs 100 cases of shingles.

context: A company's HR hires 20 new employees every month to add to its total workforce.
main-q: If the company's initial employee number is 200, and each employee is paid a $4000 salary per month, calculate the total amount of money the company pays to its employees after three months?
qa-pairs: How many employees are there in the first month?
If each month the company hire 20 new employees, the total number of employees in the company in the first month is 200 employees + 20 employees = <<200+20=220>>220 employees.
How much money is paid by the employees in the first month?
If each employee is paid $4000 per month, the total amount of money paid by the employee to its workers in the first month is 220 employees * $4000/employee = $<<220*4000=880000>>880000.
How many employees are there in the second month?
In the second month, 20 more workers are hired, bringing the total number of employees to 220 employees + 20 employees = 240 employees.
How much money is paid by the employees in the second month?
The company pays a total of 240 employees * $4000/employee = $<<240*4000=960000>>960000 in wages for its employees in the second month.
How many employees are there in the third month?
When an additional 20 workers are hired in the third month, the total number of workers become 240 employees + 20 employees = <<240+20=260>>260 employees.
How much money is paid by the employees in the third month?
In total, the company 260 employees * $4000/employee = $<<260*4000=1040000>>1040000 in wages on the third month.
How much money does the company pay to its employees in the three months?
The total amount of money the company pays to all its employees in the three months is $1040000 + $960000 + $880000 = <<1040000+960000+880000=2880000>>2880000.

context: Rose is out picking flowers for a vase she wants to fill.  She starts off by picking 3 flowers with 5 petals each.  She then picks 4 flowers with 6 petals each.  She then adds another 5 flowers with 4 petals each.  Lastly she picks 6 flowers with 7 petals each.  As she's carrying these flowers over to fill the vase, she drops 1 of each and the wind blows them away.  She puts the remaining flowers in the vase.
main-q: How many petals in total are on the flowers in the vase?
qa-pairs: How many petals are on the 5 petal flowers?
Rose picks 3*5=<<3*5=15>>15 petals worth of the 5 petal flowers.
How many petals are on the 6 petal flowers?
Rose then picks 4*6=<<4*6=24>>24 petals worth of the 6 petal flowers.
How many petals are on the 4 petal flowers?
Rose then picks 5*4=<<5*4=20>>20 petals worth of the 4 petal flowers.
How many petals are on the 7 petal flowers?
Finally, Rose picks 6*7=<<6*7=42>>42 petals worth of the 7 petal flowers.
How many petals are on the flowers in the vase?
Rose carries 15+24+20+42=<<15+24+20+42=101>>101 petals worth of flowers back to the vase.
How many petals are blown away?
But the wind blows 5+6+4+7=<<5+6+4+7=22>>22 petals worth of flowers away.
How many petals are remaining?
So Rose has 101-22=<<101-22=79>>79 petals worth remaining.

context: An interior design firm offers installation for $129.00.  It includes hanging 4 mirrors, 2 shelves, 1 chandelier, and 10 pictures.  They will install additional items for an extra $15.00 per item.  Angela has 6 mirrors and 2 chandeliers and 20 pictures that she needs installed/hung.
main-q: How much will this cost her?
qa-pairs: How many extra mirrors does Angela have?
The service includes 4 mirrors and she has 6 so that's 6-4 = <<6-4=2>>2 extra mirrors.
How much will the additional items cost?
An additional item is an extra $15.00 so that's 2*15 = $30.00.
How many extra chandeliers does Angela have?
The service includes 1 chandelier and she has 2 so that's 2-1 = 1 extra chandelier.
How much will the additional items cost?
An additional item is an extra $15.00 so that's 1*15 = $<<1*15=15.00>>15.00.
How many extra pictures does Angela have?
The service includes 10 pictures and she has 20 to that's 20-10 = <<20-10=10>>10 extra pictures.
How much will the additional items cost?
An additional item is an extra $15.00 so that's 10*15 = $<<10*15=150.00>>150.00.
How much will the service cost?
The service costs $129.00 and the extra mirrors are $30.00, the chandelier is $15.00 and the pictures are $150.00 for a total of 129+30+15+150 = $<<129+30+15+150=324.00>>324.00.

context: James loves to go swimming and has to swim across a 20-mile lake.  He can swim at a pace of 2 miles per hour.  He swims 60% of the distance.  After that, he stops on an island and rests for half as long as the swimming time.  He then finishes the remaining distance while going half the speed.
main-q: How long did it take him to get across the lake?
qa-pairs: How far did James swim?
How long did it take him to swim?
That took him 12/2=<<12/2=6>>6 hours.
How long did he rest?
So he rested 6/2=<<6/2=3>>3 hours.
How far did James swim?
He then swam the remaining 20-12=<<20-12=8>>8 miles.
How fast did James swim?
His pace was 2/2=<<2/2=1>>1 mph.
How long did it take him to swim?
So it took him 8/1=<<8/1=8>>8 hours.
How long did it take him to get across the lake?
So in total, he took 6+3+8=<<6+3+8=17>>17 hours.

context: Kim sleepwalks, to monitor her sleeping hours, she installs a camera in her room. Kim usually goes to sleep at 10 p.m. and wakes up at 6 a.m. She is a sleepwalker. One day, after reviewing the cameras, she finds that she woke up that day and was sleepwalking from 2:15 to 2:38 am.  Also, that day she woke up 5 minutes earlier than usual to go to the bathroom.
main-q: How many minutes did she sleep on her bed that day?
qa-pairs: How many hours does Kim sleep?
Out of 24 hours in a day, 10 pm represents 22 hours.
How many hours did Kim sleep?
Until 12 p.m. or 24 hours, Kim slept 24 - 22 = <<24-22=2>>2 hours.
How many hours does Kim sleep?
In total, Kim usually sleeps 2 + 6 = <<2+6=8>>8 hours a day.
How many minutes does Kim sleep?
In minutes, Kim usually sleeps 8 * 60 = <<8*60=480>>480 minutes.
How many minutes did Kim sleep?
Kim was sleepwalking for a total of 38 - 15 = <<38-15=23>>23 minutes.
How many minutes did Kim sleep?
Within her usual sleep routine, Kim was sleepwalking or awake a total of 23 + 5 =<<23+5=28>>28 minutes.
How many minutes did Kim sleep?
On that day, Kim slept in her bed for 480 - 28 = <<480-28=452>>452 minutes.

context: Sunny is selling gingerbread and apple pie for a fundraiser. On Saturday, he sold 10 boxes of gingerbread and 4 fewer boxes of apple pie, than on Sunday. On Sunday, he sold 5 more boxes of gingerbread than on Saturday and 15 boxes of apple pie.
main-q: If the gingerbread cost $6 and the apple pie cost $15, how much did Sunny earn for two days?
qa-pairs: How many boxes of gingerbread did Sunny sell on Sunday?
He sold 10 + 5 = <<10+5=15>>15 boxes of gingerbread on Sunday.
How many boxes of gingerbread did Sunny sell in total?
The total number of boxes of gingerbread that Sunny sold is 10 + 15 = <<10+15=25>>25.
How much did Sunny earn for selling gingerbread?
Sunny earned 25 x $6 = $<<25*6=150>>150 for selling gingerbread.
How many boxes of apple pie did Sunny sell on Saturday?
He sold 15 - 4 = <<15-4=11>>11 boxes of apple pie on Saturday.
How many boxes of apple pie did Sunny sell in total?
The total number of boxes of apple pie that Sunny sold is 15 + 11 = <<15+11=26>>26.
How much did Sunny earn for selling apple pie?
He earned 26 x $15 = $<<26*15=390>>390 for selling apple pie.
How much did Sunny earn for two days?
So, Sunny earned $150 + $390 = $<<150+390=540>>540 for two days.

context: Betsy and Donovan made a meal together. Betsy's part took 18 minutes longer than Donovan's part. The meal was made in 98 minutes.
main-q: How many minutes long was Betsy's part?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let D = Donovan's time in minutes.
How long was Betsy's part?
Write an equation?
Simplify?
Simplify?
How long was Betsy's part?
How many minutes long was Betsy's part?
Betsy's part took 58 minutes.

context: Paul is at a train station and is waiting for his train. He isn't sure how long he needs to wait, but he knows that the fourth train scheduled to arrive at the station is the one he needs to get on. The first train is scheduled to arrive in 10 minutes, and this train will stay in the station for 20 minutes. The second train is to arrive half an hour after the first train leaves the station, and this second train will stay in the station for a quarter of the amount of time that the first train stayed in the station. The third train is to arrive an hour after the second train leaves the station, and this third train is to leave the station immediately after it arrives.  The fourth train will arrive 20 minutes after the third train leaves, and this is the train Paul will board.
main-q: In total, how long, in minutes, will Paul wait for his train?
qa-pairs: How long does the first train stay in the station?
The first train stays in the station for 10 minutes * 2 = <<10*2=20>>20 minutes.
How long does Paul wait for the first train?
So Paul waits for the first train for 20 + 10 = <<20+10=30>>30 minutes.
How long after the first train does the second train arrive?
The second train arrives after half an hour, which is the same as 60 minutes / 2 = <<60/2=30>>30 minutes.
How long does the second train stay in the station?
It then stays in the station for a quarter of the time the first train did which is 20 minutes / 4 = <<20/4=5>>5 minutes.
How long does Paul wait for the second train?
So Paul waits for the second train for 30 + 5 = <<30+5=35>>35 minutes.
How long after the second train does the third train arrive?
The third train arrives an hour later, which is the same as 60 minutes * 1 hour = <<60*1=60>>60 minutes.
How long, in minutes, will Paul wait for his train?

After the final wait, Paul has waited a total of 30 minutes for the first train + 35 minutes for the second train + 60 minutes for the third train + 20 minutes final wait = <<30+35+60+20=145>>145 minutes.

context: Tony is painting a room with four walls. The north and south walls are 10 x 8 feet. The east and west walls are 5 x 8 feet. A gallon of paint can cover 20 square feet and cost $12.
main-q: How much will it cost to paint the room?
qa-pairs: How many square feet are the north and south walls?
The north and south walls are 80 square feet each because 10 x 8 = <<10*8=80>>80.
How many square feet are the east and west walls?
The east and west walls are 40 square feet because 5 x 8 = <<5*8=40>>40.
How many square feet are the south and north walls?
The south and north walls total 160 square feet because 80 x 2 = <<80*2=160>>160.
How many square feet are the east and west walls?
The East and west walls total 80 square feet because 40 x 2 = <<40*2=80>>80.
How many square feet are all the walls?
All the walls total 240 square feet because 160 + 80 = <<160+80=240>>240.
How many gallons of paint will he need?
He will need 12 gallons of paint because 240 / 20 = <<240/20=12>>12.
How much will it cost?
It will cost $144 because 12 x 12 = <<12*12=144>>144.

context: Sheila charged $85.00 worth of merchandise on her credit card.  She ended up returning one item that cost $15.00.  After she returned the item, she bought a frying pan that was on sale for 20% off $20.00 and a set of towels that was 10% off $30.00.  She put both of these purchases on her credit card.
main-q: What is the new balance on her credit card?
qa-pairs: How much did Sheila charge on her card?
She charged $85.00 on her card and just returned a $15.00 purchase so right now, her credit card has 85-15 = $<<85-15=70.00>>70.00 balance.
How much did the frying pan cost?
How much did the frying pan cost?
The frying pan costs $20.00 and the discount price is $4.00 so the new price is 20-4=$<<20-4=16.00>>16.00.
How much did the towel set cost?
How much did the towel set cost?
The towel set costs $30.00 and the discount price is $3.00 so the new price is 30-3= $<<30-3=27.00>>27.00.
How much did Sheila spend?
Her new purchases total 16+27 = $$<<16+27=43.00>>43.00.
What is the new balance on her credit card?
After the return, her card balance was $70.00 and she just added $43.00 in purchases so her new balance is 70+43 = $<<70+43=113.00>>113.00.

context: Cole hid 3 dozen eggs in the yard for the Easter egg hunt.  Lamar finds 5 eggs. Stacy finds twice as many as Lamar.  Charlie finds 2 less than Stacy.  And Mei finds half as many as Charlie.
main-q: How many eggs are still hidden in the yard?
qa-pairs: How many eggs does Cole hide?
Cole hides 3 x 12 = <<3*12=36>>36 eggs.
How many eggs does Lamar find?
Lamar finds 5 eggs.
How many eggs does Stacy find?
Stacy finds 5 x 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 eggs.
How many eggs does Charlie find?
Charlie finds 10 - 2 = <<10-2=8>>8 eggs.
How many eggs does Mei find?
Mei finds 8 / 2 = <<8/2=4>>4 eggs.
How many eggs do the children find?
The children find a total of 5 + 10 + 8 + 4 = <<5+10+8+4=27>>27 eggs.
How many eggs are still hidden in the yard?
The total number of hidden eggs still in the yard is 36 - 27 = <<36-27=9>>9 eggs.

context: A teacher uses a 5-inch piece of chalk to write math equations on a chalkboard for his students. The teacher likes to conserve chalk, so he tries to only use 20% of the chalk each day. Since the teacher cannot write with a very small piece of chalk, he recycles the chalk when it is smaller than 2 inches. On Monday the teacher used a new piece of chalk. His students need extra help that day, so he ended up writing more than usual. He used up 45% of the chalk by the end of the day.
main-q: If the teacher goes back to using only 20% of the chalk each day, how many days does he have before he has to recycle this piece?
qa-pairs: How many inches of chalk does the teacher use on Monday?
The teacher uses 45% of his 5 inch stick of chalk on Monday, or 5 * .45 = <<5*.45=2.25>>2.25 inches.
How many inches of chalk does the teacher have left after Monday?
He is left with 5 - 2.25 = <<5-2.25=2.75>>2.75 inches of chalk.
How many inches of chalk does the teacher use on Tuesday?
The next day he will use 20% of 2.75 inches, which is 2.75 * .2 = <<2.75*.2=.55>>.55 inches of chalk used.
How many inches of chalk does the teacher have left after Tuesday?
That leaves him with 2.75 - .55 = <<2.75-.55=2.2>>2.2 inches of chalk.
How many inches of chalk does the teacher use on Wednesday?
The day after that, he will use 2.2 * .2 = <<2.2*.2=.44>>.44 inches of chalk.
How many inches of chalk does the teacher have left after Wednesday?
That will leave him with 2.2 - .44 = <<2.2-.44=1.76>>1.76 inches of chalk.
How many days does the teacher have before he has to recycle this piece?
Since 1.76 is less than 2 inches, he will recycle this stick in 2 days.

context: Pauline visits her favorite local museum three times a year. The cost of one visit is $2. After 5 years, the cost of one visit has increased by 150%, but Pauline decided not to give up any visit and continued to go to the museum for 3 more years.
main-q: How much did Pauline spend on all visits to the museum?
qa-pairs: How much did Pauline pay every year?
Pauline visited the local museum 3 times a year, so she paid 3 * 2 = $<<3*2=6>>6 every year on visits.
How much did Pauline spend on tickets?
That means during the first 5 years Pauline spend 5 * 6 = $<<5*6=30>>30 on tickets.
How much did the cost of one visit increase?
After 5 years the cost of one visit increased by 150/100 * 2 = $<<150/100*2=3>>3.
What was the new price of the ticket?
That means the new price of the ticket was 2 + 3 = $<<2+3=5>>5.
How much did Pauline pay every year?
So for per year Pauline paid 3 * 5 = $<<3*5=15>>15.
How much did Pauline spend on all visits?
During the last 3 years, she paid in total 3 * 15 = $<<3*15=45>>45.
How much did Pauline spend on all visits?
In total Pauline spend 30 + 45 = $<<30+45=75>>75 on visits at the museum.

context: The power goes out in Brianna's house one night so she and her family gather all their candles and flashlights. There are 8 rooms in the house and 4 people living there, including Brianna. There is a flashlight for every person to carry and two for each room. They have a variety of candles available; 4 small candles each for half the rooms and 5 medium candles each for the other half of the rooms.
main-q: With everything combined, how many candles and flashlights are Brianna's family using when the lights go out?
qa-pairs: How many flashlights are there?
For every one of the 8 rooms in the house, there are 2 flashlights, 8 x 2 = <<8*2=16>>16 flashlights.
How many flashlights are there?
For every person there is 1 flashlight, 1 x 4 people = <<1*4=4>>4 flashlights.
How many flashlights are there?
Total, there are 16 + 4 = <<16+4=20>>20 flashlights in the house being used by Brianna and her family.
How many small candles are there?
For half of the 8 rooms, there are 4 small candles each, 8/2 x 4 = <<8/2*4=16>>16 small candles in half the rooms.
How many medium candles are there?
For the other half of the 8 rooms, there are 5 medium candles each, 8/2 x 5 = <<8/2*5=20>>20 medium candles in all the rooms.
How many candles are there?
Total, there are 16 + 20 = <<16+20=36>>36 candles in the house.
How many flashlights and candles are there?
Combined, there are 20 flashlights + 36 candles = <<20+36=56>>56 flashlights and candles in the house.

context: Every day Charisma meditates for 15 minutes when she first wakes up and again before she goes to sleep.  5 days a week she practices 1 hour of yoga.
main-q: in 4 weeks, how much time has she spent on meditation/yoga practice?
qa-pairs: How many minutes does Charisma meditate in the morning and at night?
She meditates for 15 minutes in the morning and 15 minutes at night for a total of 15+15 = <<15+15=30>>30 minutes.
How many minutes does Charisma meditate in a week?
She meditates 30 minutes daily so in 7 days/1 week she meditates 30*7 = <<30*7=210>>210 minutes.
How many minutes does Charisma meditate in 4 weeks?
She meditates 210 minutes in 1 week so in 4 weeks she meditates 210*4 = <<210*4=840>>840 minutes.
How many hours does Charisma meditate in 4 weeks?
60 minutes are in an hour so she meditates for 840/60 = <<840/60=14>>14 hours.
How many hours does Charisma practice yoga?
She practices yoga for 1 hour 5 days a week so that's 1*5 = <<1*5=5>>5 hours.
How many hours does Charisma practice yoga?
Over 4 weeks she practices yoga for 4*5 = <<4*5=20>>20 hours.
How many hours has Charisma spent on meditation/yoga practice?
She spends 14 hours meditating and 20 hours practicing yoga for a total of 14+20 = <<14+20=34>>34 hours.
